section.name: dalma:dar goal
section.p: This goal builds a dalma archive (.dar) for the project. This mostly works in the same way as the jar goal --- it puts the same resources and class files as with the jar goal, it puts the same additional files specified by the maven.jar.includes property.
In addition to those files, this goal supports the following two features:

ol.li: Puts the Dalma-Main-Class attribute to the manifest, as specified by the maven.dalma.mainclass property.

If dependency jar files in the manifest has dar.bundle property as follows, bundle those jar file s in the generated dar file. This makes it easy to redistribute libraries that your workflow application uses.

section.name: dalma:genapp goal
section.p: This goal works like the genapp goal, and produces a skeleton of a new workflow project into the current directory.
This is a handy goal when you are starting a new workflow applciation. It creates project.xml and a few other files.

section.name: dalma:run goal
section.p: This goal uses <dalmaRunner> ant task to run your current workflow application project. This is handy when you are debugging it.
To attach a debugger, run Maven with JPDA enabled, as follows:

This goal consults the maven.dalma.mainclass property for the main Program class. Dependencies marked with <dar.bundle>true</dar.bundle> will be passed as a classpath to the dalmaRunner ant task, therefore they become a subject to the byte code instrumentation.

Maven properties that start with prefix "dalma.test." will be passed as properties and used to configure resources. For example, a property dalma.test.xyz=5 will be used to inject "5" into a field @Resource int xyz;.
